AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: Malus pumila is the domesticated Apple tree that occasionally escapes from cultivation. In the published literature and on the internet, a confusing variety of scientific names refer to this tree: Malus communis, Malus domestica, Malus pumila, Malus sylvestris, and Pyrus malus. Of these, Malus pumila is the preferred scientific name for both cultivated and naturalized Apple trees. Because naturalized trees may hybridize with other Malus spp. (Crab Apples), identification of wild trees can be difficult, particularly around urban and suburban areas. In general, Apple has larger fruits (1½" across or more) than Crab Apples. It also has leaves that are short-pubescent on their undersides and they lack lateral lobes. The native Crab Apples have smaller greenish yellow fruits and their leaves are often shallowly lobed. Some animals such as the black bear, grouse, and white-tailed deer use the buds, twigs and fruit as a food source.
Gray brown to pale purple-brown, scaly. With age develops thin, peeling flakes.
1-1 1/2" wide, showy; white tinged with pink. Five rounded petals. Each flower on long stalk in small clusters. Fragrant.
2-4" wide, round pome; depressed at both ends. Late summer, early autumn

Alternate 2-3½" long and 1¼-2¼" across, occur along the twigs and young shoots. The leaf blades are lanceolate-ovate to ovate and finely serrated or crenulated along margins. The upper surface of the leaf blades is yellowish green to dark green and hairless, pale gray green or whitish and downylower surface.
Edible fruit, distinguished from that of crab apples by being greater than 2" wide.

ThemeEntityData.Description: Malus pumila is the domesticated Apple tree that occasionally escapes from cultivation. In the published literature and on the internet, a confusing variety of scientific names refer to this tree: Malus communis, Malus domestica, Malus pumila, Malus sylvestris, and Pyrus malus. Of these, Malus pumila is the preferred scientific name for both cultivated and naturalized Apple trees. Because naturalized trees may hybridize with other Malus spp. (Crab Apples), identification of wild trees can be difficult, particularly around urban and suburban areas. In general, Apple has larger fruits (1½" across or more) than Crab Apples. It also has leaves that are short-pubescent on their undersides and they lack lateral lobes. The native Crab Apples have smaller greenish yellow fruits and their leaves are often shallowly lobed. Some animals such as the black bear, grouse, and white-tailed deer use the buds, twigs and fruit as a food source.
